prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC7496
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in the centre of NGC7496 with a minimum of a S/N=5 for the weakest lines (C2H and CS).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have calculated the expected fluxes of HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected in this galaxy with the SEST telescope (Elfhag et al. 1996). We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068 to predict the intensities in NGC7496 with ALMA: HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.12, HCO+(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.09, C2H(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.03, CS(2-1)/CO(1-0)=0.03. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in both galaxies, as they are alike in almost all observed properties (Elfhag et al 1996). The observed CO(1-0) line in NGC7496 has a main beam temperature of 40 mK, equivalent to 472 mJy as would be seen by ALMA with an 1" resolution.
The expected fluxes are HCN(1-0)=3.5 mJy, HCO+(1-0)=2.6 mJy, and C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1)=0.9 mJy. We aim to detect the weakest lines with a S/N=5, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 0.3 mJy at a final velocity resolution of 20km/s.

The spectral windows are chosen to oberve HCO(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to observe them all simultaneously. The CO(1-0) detected line in this galaxy has a line-width of 130 km/s. The proposed molecules are not expected to be broarder, so we take this value as a reference. We will average to 4 spectral channels, with a final resolution in velocities of 20 km/s. This way, we will have 7 channels per line.

To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales ~100 pc which, at the distances of our objects, corresponds to a 1" resolution. The AGN emission of NGC7496 is concentrated in the central 1" (Wilson et al. 1991), which we do not aim to resolve. The starburst ring is located at ~1 Kpc (3") from the centre. While we do not aim to resolve any of the two contributions, the propsed angular resolution of 1" (70 pc in NGC7496) will allow us to separate both emissions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC4691
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in the centre of NGC4691 with a minimum of a S/N=5 for the weakest lines (C2H and CS).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have calculated the expected fluxes of HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) detected line in this galaxy with the SEST telescope (Tacconi et al.1991). We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068 to predict the intensities in NGC4691 with ALMA: HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.12, HCO+(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.09, C2H(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.03, CS(2-1)/CO(1-0)=0.03. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in both galaxies. CO(1-0) has a main beam temperature of 141 mK with SEST, equivalent to 13.3 Jy; the flux of this line with ALMA at 1" resolution would be 2.8 Jy assuming a source size of 4". The expected flux at 1" resolution for the weakest lines, C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1), is 5.3 mJy. We aim to detect these lines with a S/N=5, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 1.0 mJy.

The spectral windows are chosen to oberve HCO(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to observe them all simultaneously. The CO(1-0) detected line in this galaxy has a line-width of 100 km/s. The proposed molecules are not expected to be broarder, so we take this value as a reference. We will smooth to a final resolution in velocities of 10 km/s. This way, we will have 10 channels per line.

To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales ~100 pc which, at the distance of NGC4691, corresponds to 1" resolution. We assume that the source size of NGC4691 is similar to that of NGC1068: 4". NGC4691 is at a larger distance (23 Mpc) than NGC1068 (14 Mpc), and it is very unlike that the source size of the former is larger than 4". There is a vigorous star-forming region at ~20" distance to the centre, which is a smaller size than the maximum recoverage scale at 1" resolution in Band 3. While we do not aim to resolve any of the two contributions (AGN and starburst), the propsed angular resolution of 1" will allow us to separate both emissions.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC4593
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in the centre of NGC4593 with a minimum of a S/N=5 for the weakest lines (C2H and CS).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have calculated the expected fluxes of the HCN(1-0) HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected in this galaxy (Rigopoulou et al. 1997). We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068 to predict the intensities in NGC4593 with ALMA: HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.12, HCO+(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.09, C2H(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.03, CS(2-1)/CO(1-0)=0.03. These relative intensities are expeceted to be similar in both galaxies.
The observed CO(1-0) line has a main beam temperature of 358.7 mJy as observed with SEST. The central AGN is very compact, with sub-arsecond size. We assume a source size of 1". The expected fluxes of the weakest lines, C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1), have an expected of flux 11 mJy, as seen by ALMA with 1" resolution. We aim to detect them with a S/N>5, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 2.2 mJy.

The spectral windows are chosen to oberve HCO(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to observe them all simultaneously. The CO(1-0) detected line in this galaxy has a line-width of 260 km/s. The proposed molecules are not expected to be broarder, so we take this value as a reference. We will average to 4 spectral channels, with a final resolution in velocities of 20 km/s. This way, we will have ~10 channels per line.

To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales ~100 pc which, at the distances of NGC4593, corresponds to a 1" resolution. The AGN compact emission of NGC7496 is concentrated within the central 1" (Santos-Lleou et al. 1995), which we do not aim to resolve.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC7213
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in the centre of NGC7213 with a minimum of a S/N=5 for the weakest lines (C2H and CS).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have calculated the expected fluxes of the HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected in this galaxy with the SEST telescope (Wikling et al. 1991). We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068 to predict the intensities in NGC77213 with ALMA: HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.12, HCO+(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.09, C2H(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.03, CS(2-1)/CO(1-0)=0.03.These relative intensities are expected to be similar in NGC1068 and NGC7213. The observed CO(1-0) line in NGC7213 has a main beam temperature of 60 mK, equivalent to 1.3Jy.
The fluxes of the two weakes transitions, C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1), as seen by ALMA at 1" resolution are expected to be 2.4 mJy. We aim to detect them with a S/N=5, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 0.9 mJy at a final velocity resolution of 30km/s.

The spectral windows are chosen to oberve HCO(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to observe them all simultaneously. The CO(1-0) detected line in this galaxy has a line-width of 280 km/s. The proposed molecules are not expected to be broarder, so we take this value as a reference. We will average to 4 spectral channels, with a final resolution in velocities of 20 km/s. This way, we will have ~10 channels per line.

To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales ~100 pc which, at the distance of NGC7213, corresponds to a ~1" resolution. The AGN emission of NGC7213 is expected to be concentrated in a maximum of 4", which we do not aim to resolve.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC4941
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in the centre of NGC4941 with a minimum of a S/N=5 for the weakest lines (C2H and CS).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have calculated the expected fluxes of HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected in this galaxy with single dish observations (282 mK, Mao et al. 2010). The observed CO(1-0) line in NGC4941 is 13.6 mJy as would be seen by ALMA with at 1" resolution. We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068 to predict the intensities in NGC4941 with ALMA: HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.12, HCO+(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.09, C2H(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.03, CS(2-1)/CO(1-0)=0.03. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in NGC1068 and NGC4941.
The expected fluxes of the two weakest lines C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1), as seen by ALMA at 1" resolution are 25.5 mJy. We aim to detect them with a S/N=5, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 5.0 mJy at a final velocity resolution of 5km/s.

The spectral windows are chosen to oberve HCO(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to observe them all simultaneously. The CO(1-0) detected line in this galaxy has a line-width of 50 km/s. The proposed molecules are not expected to be broarder, so we take this value as a reference. We will average to 4 spectral channels, with a final resolution in velocities of 1 km/s.

To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales ~100 pc which, at the distances of NGC4941, corresponds to a 1" resolution. We expect the emission of NGC4941 to be concentrated in the central 4" (as in NGC1068; both galaxies lie at similar distance), which we do not aim to resolve.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC1672
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in the centre of NGC1972 with a minimum of a S/N=5 for the weakest lines (C2H and CS).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have calculated the expected fluxes of HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected in this galaxy with the SEST telescope (Bajaja et al. 1995). We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068 to predict the intensities in NGC1672 with ALMA: HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.12, HCO+(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.09, C2H(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.03, CS(2-1)/CO(1-0)=0.03. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in both galaxies, as thay are very alike in almost all observed properties (Bajaja et al 1995). The observed CO(1-0) line in NGC1672 has a main beam temperature of 115 mK, equivalent to 472 mJy as would be seen by ALMA with an 1" resolution.
The expected fluxes of the weakest lines C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1), as seen by ALMA at 1" resolution are 4.3 Jy. We aim to detect with lines with a S/N=5, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 0.9 mJy at a final velocity resolution of 20km/s (see below).

The spectral windows are chosen to oberve HCO(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to observe them all simultaneously. The CO(1-0) detected line in this galaxy has a line-width of 200 km/s. The proposed molecules are not expected to be broarder, so we take this value as a reference. We will average to 4 spectral channels, with a final resolution in velocities of 20 km/s. This way, we will have 10 channels per line.

To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales ~100 pc which, at the distances of NGC1672, corresponds to a ~1" resolution. The source size of NGC1672 is not expecte to be larger than 4" (as in NGC1068; both galaxies lie at similar distances), and we do not aim to resolve it

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC7469
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to detect HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) in the centre of NGC7469 with a minimum of a S/N=5 for the weakest lines (C2H and CS).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral windows are chosen to oberve HCO(1-0) and HCO+(1-0) (spw=1), C2H(1-0) (spw=2) and CS(2-1) (spw=3), maximizing the bandwidth to observe them all simultaneously. The CO(1-0) detected line in this galaxy has a line-width of 240 km/s. The proposed molecules are not expected to be broarder, so we take this value as a reference. We will average to 4 spectral channels, with a final resolution in velocities of 20 km/s. This way, we will have more than 12 channels per line.

To test the influence of the environments in the proposed galaxies, we aim to resolve scales ~100 pc which, at the distances of NGC7469, corresponds to a ~1" resolution. The AGN emission of NGC7496 is concentrated within the central 1" (Wilson et al. 1991), which we do not aim to resolve. The starburst ring is located at ~1 Kpc (3") from the centre. While we do not aim to resolve any of the two contributions, the propsed angular resolution of 1" will allow us to separate both emissions.

We have calculated the expected fluxes of HCN(1-0), HCO+(1-0), C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1) from the CO(1-0) line detected in this galaxy with the IRAM PdBI (Davies et al. 2003). We used the relative intensities among these molecules observed in NGC1068 to predict the intensities in NGC7469 with ALMA: HCN(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.12, HCO+(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.09, C2H(1-0)/CO(1-0)=0.03, CS(2-1)/CO(1-0)=0.03. These relative intensities are expected to be similar in NGC1068 and NGC7496, as both galaxies are very similar in almost all observed properties (Wilson et al 1991). The observed CO(1-0) line in NGC7469 has a temperature of 300 mJy km/s with 2" resolution with the PdBI.
The expected fluxes of the two faintest lines, C2H(1-0) and CS(2-1), as seen with ALMA at 1" resolution are 5 mJy. We aim to detect the weakest lines with a S/N=5, so our desired sensitivity per pointing is 1 mJy at a final velocity resolution of 20km/s (see below).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Seyfert (Sy) 2 galaxies are found to have interactions with nearby galaxies more frequently than Sy1's. This increases the starbursts processes in the formers, which fuel with more gas and dust the regions close to the central engines. It might well be that the larger amounts of dust obscure the broad-line regions (BLR), leading to the optical features that characterize them in opposition to Sy1 types (as stated by the unification theories). It has been proposed that as the starbursts exhaust the gas, the obscuration of the torus decreases, while the black hole grows and the material is eventually expelled, allowing the BLR to be visible, leading to Sy1 typical spectra.
We propose a study of HCN, HCO+, CS and C2H in Band 3 to look for trends between the evolution of dense, star-forming gas near the nuclei and Seyfert classification. We will also constrain the strength of UV fields and cosmic rays in different Seyferts. The results will be contrasted to existing infrared data (Herschel, Spire) to search for relations between host dust from the inner tori and larger scales of by gas/dust probed with ALMA
